title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

code: ## Process and recode RAM-OP data (testSVY) df <- create_op_all(svy = testSVY)  ## Perform probit estimation on recoded data using appropriate weights provided by testPSU probitDF <- estimate_probit(x = df, w = testPSU) #> # A tibble: 3 × 10 #>   INDICATOR  EST.ALL   LCL.ALL UCL.ALL EST.MALES LCL.MALES UCL.MALES EST.FEMALES #>   <chr>        <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 GAM       0.0366     1.37e-2 0.0479   6.02e- 3  8.33e- 4  0.0115       0.0549  #> 2 MAM       0.0326     1.36e-2 0.0478   5.84e- 3  7.71e- 4  0.0115       0.0505  #> 3 SAM       0.000219   2.07e-6 0.00659  2.19e-10  2.59e-21  0.000160     0.00255 #> # ℹ 2 more variables: LCL.FEMALES <dbl>, UCL.FEMALES <dbl> ## Merge classicDF and probitDF resultsDF <- merge_estimates(x = classicDF, y = probitDF)  resultsDF #> # A tibble: 139 × 13 #>    INDICATOR GROUP       LABEL TYPE  EST.ALL LCL.ALL UCL.ALL EST.MALES LCL.MALES #>    <fct>     <fct>       <fct> <fct>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1 resp1     Survey      Resp… Prop…  0.859   0.794   0.880     0.803     0.743  #>  2 resp2     Survey      Resp… Prop…  0.0885  0.075   0.152     0.1       0.0308 #>  3 resp3     Survey      Resp… Prop…  0.0417  0.0219  0.0729    0.0658    0.0309 #>  4 resp4     Survey      Resp… Prop…  0       0       0.0229    0.0132    0      #>  5 age       Demography… Mean… Mean  70.7    69.4    72.1      71.0      69.3    #>  6 ageGrp1   Demography… Self… Prop…  0       0       0         0         0      #>  7 ageGrp2   Demography… Self… Prop…  0.536   0.441   0.586     0.470     0.423  #>  8 ageGrp3   Demography… Self… Prop…  0.229   0.181   0.328     0.325     0.211  #>  9 ageGrp4   Demography… Self… Prop…  0.198   0.123   0.277     0.153     0.0890 #> 10 ageGrp5   Demography… Self… Prop…  0.0365  0.0219  0.0573    0.0488    0.0236 #> # ℹ 129 more rows #> # ℹ 4 more variables: UCL.MALES <dbl>, EST.FEMALES <dbl>, LCL.FEMALES <dbl>, #> #   UCL.FEMALES <dbl>

what: An Implementation of Rapid Assessment Method for Older People
title: An Implementation of Rapid Assessment Method for Older People
text: HelpAge International, VALID International, Brixton Health, financial assistance Humanitarian Innovation Fund (HIF), developed Rapid Assessment Method Older People (RAM-OP) provides accurate reliable estimates needs older people. method uses simple procedures, short time frame (.e. two weeks including training, data collection, data entry, data analysis), considerably lower cost methods. RAM-OP method based following principles: Use familiar “household survey” design employing two-stage cluster sample design optimised allow use small primary sample (m ≥ 16 clusters) small overall (n ≥ 192) sample. Assessment multiple dimensions need older people (including prevalence global, moderate severe acute malnutrition) using, whenever possible, standard well-tested indicators question sets. Data analysis performed using modern computer-intensive methods allow estimates indicator levels made useful precision using small sample size.

title: An Implementation of Rapid Assessment Method for Older People
text: can install oldr CRAN : can install development version oldr GitHub :
code: install.packages("oldr") if(!require(remotes)) install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("rapidsurveys/oldr")

what: An Implementation of Rapid Assessment Method for Older People (RAM-OP) — oldr
title: An Implementation of Rapid Assessment Method for Older People (RAM-OP) — oldr
text: HelpAge International, VALID International, Brixton Health, financial assistance Humanitarian Innovation Fund (HIF), developed Rapid Assessment Method Older People (RAM-OP) provides accurate reliable estimates needs older people. method uses simple procedures, short time frame (.e. two weeks including training, data collection, data entry, data analysis), considerably lower cost methods.

title: An Implementation of Rapid Assessment Method for Older People (RAM-OP) — oldr
text: RAM-OP method based following principles: Use familiar “household survey” design employing two-stage cluster sample design optimised allow use small primary sample (\(m \geq 16\) clusters) small overall (\(n \geq 192\)) sample. Assessment multiple dimensions need older people (including prevalence global, moderate severe acute malnutrition) using, whenever possible, standard well-tested indicators question sets. Data analysis performed using modern computer-intensive methods allow estimates indicator levels made useful precision using small sample size. See README GitHub details

title: An Implementation of Rapid Assessment Method for Older People (RAM-OP) — oldr
text: Maintainer: Ernest Guevarra ernest@guevarra.io (ORCID) Authors: Mark Myatt mark@brixtonhealth.com (ORCID) Pascale Fritsch Katja Siling
